description: From Middle English however, how-ever, how-evere; equivalent to how +‎ ever. Compare howsoever.

entries.meaning: (conjunctive) Nevertheless; yet, still; in spite of that.
examples: He told me not to do it. However, I did it anyway. / I did it anyway, however. / I, however, did it anyway.
She wanted to go; however, she decided against it.
I didn't argue with him; I still think, however, that he is wrong.
The conference itself went very well. The party afterwards, however, was a disaster.
However clear you think you've been, many questions will remain.

entries.meaning: (informal, manner) In any way that one likes or chooses; in a haphazard or spontaneous way.
examples: I don't care; just do it however.
Nothing was really planned; things just happened however.

entries.meaning: (interrogative) How ever: an emphatic form of how, used to ask in what manner.
examples: I thought it was impossible. However were you able to do it?

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In any case, at any rate, at all events.
examples: Our chief end and highest interest is happiness : And this is happiness to be freed from all (if it may) [or] however from the greatest evils.
